text: well hello my name is Brenda mathys I'm
an assistant professor at Leslie
University in the school of education in
the technology and education division
and I'm also president of Mathis
Brothers software pathology and we
examine websites and software for unfair
outcomes and the lecture that I'll be
giving is
about biases in software and websites
really looking at what I call the the
other side of the screen you know what's
on the other side of this screen with
who are the people who make the
decisions and what are decisions are
made about the design and how it affects
us as
users there are about three key points
I'm going to bring up in the lecture the
first one talks about text and Graphics
Now text and Graphics is a very very big
issue because it affects most everyone
who uses software and websites what I'm
talking about is basically about
accessibility for those who need to have
bigger text those who have low vision
and those who are blind uh one of the
major issues about websites is that um
they're be they become more more graphic
oriented so there's more pictures and
that's very wonderful except if you
can't see them or if you just can't
navigate through them and many many
people not only in the United States but
in other countries use text to speech
readers when you have a text to speech
reader and it comes across a website
that has Graphics most likely it's not
going to be able to read those Graphics
it'll just say Graphics so you really
don't know what's going on but if you
have a website that has a picture with
graphics and then there's text
information hidden behind the graphics
so that the text reader speech to text
reader knows and says to you oh this is
a beautiful pict it won't say oh but it
say it's a picture of the the temps in
London then that really helps that
person understand what's going on and
also the person who has Vision can see
what's going on another alternative to
that issue is having two versions a text
version and a graphics version Let Me
Show an example of that one of the
people who have done a good job about
that is Stephen Hawking the famous
scientist now before you go to his
website he has this page that says
welcome to Professor Steven W Hawkins
web pages and these Pages have been
designed to make access to the
information as straightforward as
possible this is a very key statement
because he's actually saying to you
explicitly we know what the issues are
and we want to make sure that you get
the information that's best for you
partly because Stephen Hawking um is
disabled himself and has a lot of
accessible tools to help him I think
he's also thinking about that audience
but many other people are also thinking
in the same way so let's look what
happens when you go to the graphic
version you have the graphic
version and you have all the pictures
and all the beautiful graphics and
hyperlinks which you probably would not
be able to use if you um have a vision
impairment or a blind or um and actually
the text is very small too I have to
write to them about that however if you
go to the text only version
here and you see it's all in text and I
apologize to you my text of speech uh
software is not working today but I'll
show you in uh an example of this uh in
the lecture itself but what'll happen is
that the text of speech reader will read
each of these lines and read it out loud
and the person will be able to see and
hear everything that's on the graphic
part of that page so that's a wonderful
thing another important issue is
language and there are two issues about
language one in terms of software one in
terms of
websites in terms of websites
most websites are in English because
most of the websites are based in the
United States but there are many many
more websites coming up in different
parts of the world and they want to make
sure that they address English uh
speaking audiences as well as their own
audiences so many websites are now
becoming bilingual trilingual multiable
you'll find many websites that have
different languages most of those
websites are not based in the United
States
so the point is is that if you have a
website remember that many many of your
audience members are not in the United
States there are many people surfing
that are not in the US and also many
people in the US who actually have
different languages that as their mother
languages and would be greatly
appreciative of having a website that
has information in different languages
for them this is a very key issue it
also talks about a digital divide and
accessibility which we'll talk about a
little bit in the class as well another
issue about language is software now let
me give you a specific example in in the
recent uh recent years I've been
researching educational software for
children and several years ago I did a
small study about educational software
for children the top 10 selling software
in school in the math category of those
top 10 software titles
um most all of them didn't have
English and another language they only
have one language and then if they did
have another language it was not totally
in that second language it'll be in
Spanish and it U maybe will have French
but it will have English for navigation
so that sent the message that you know
it's not fully bilingual and maybe you
really don't need to have everything in
Spanish or English or maybe it was
perhaps an oversight but it happens all
the time so it's sort of a key issue for
children to make sure and for adults
actually to make sure that when you use
a software that has more than one
language that it has to be completely in
each language another issue about
software is about
gender uh and specifically about
educational software uh gender is a is a
big issue in the same study I looked at
uh the top 10 selling math software and
found that most of the titles did not
have girls represented or girls were
represented in an ancillary way they
were in the background but they were not
part of the action they were not
speaking they were just really graphics
and so this sent a message to young
girls especially in in such a crucial
situation where
children uh going into sixth grade are
starting to have more interest in
different top topics and girls generally
check out of math but here you have math
software that does not show girls
participating in math and that sends a
message so there's a bias there there's
a bias toward boys or a bias against
girls there and so you have to look at a
lot of different things for websites and
software you have to look at gender you
have to look at nationality language
accessibility so many different issues
so the question becomes how do you
address all of these issues how do you
know about
them one of the exciting things about
the answer to that question is that many
software designers software developers
web designers are now being specifically
trained either in the workplace or in
educational institutions on how to
support different types of users by
Design and also to look at the ethics
behind the design not only the graphical
interface but also what is the logic in
the
software the other issue the other um
big important change that's happening is
the consumers are starting to become
more aware parents and teachers and just
general consumers are looking at what
does this software offer me if I'm
speaking Spanish and English is the
software in Spanish and English if I'm
going to use this from my child are
there different types of children being
represented I have uh several parents
who come to me on a regular basis asking
me what software is out there that um
will be fun for my child but also it's
not biased toward just having you know
just kids of one nationality represented
I want my child to be of the world in
real life and I wanted them to be of the
World when they use their software
what's out there so people are becoming
more and more aware of this and we're
going to talk about this and other
issues in the class and I look forward
to having a conversation with you I'll
see see you there
